You raise a glass and stare Katey in the eye: "To women." Merrily, she joins your toast, and you both knock back another shot of whiskey. And another. 

The crowd packs in, and even your booth in the back starts feeling a little crowded. Katey rests her cheek on your shoulder. You think she says something about her girlfriend, and moving out of the city. 

You tell her how Emily makes you feel. Honestly. 

> [[You can barely hear yourself, anymore|day05_startd]]

passages.name: day06_01
passages.text:
Her knock is more confident than last time. "Sorry," you say, opening the door. "My hair's still wet, and—" 

It's not Emily. 

"Hey, we just wanted to see if you got our note." Your upstairs neighbor, Sylvia, has a slight Spanish accent; you're fairly sure she's Dominican. Her boyfriend is dark-skinned and handsome and ripped. 
<<if not $weirdCall>>
"Note?" 

But now Emily is walking up, and your neighbors look eager to leave. "Sorry, all we had was a napkin. We're gone for the weekend, but we'll drop in later, yeah?" 

Marcus fist bumps you, and they're gone.<<else>>
"Oh, yeah, I was hoping to catch you two. What kind of weird guy?" Marcus, the boyfriend, begins to sign something, and you gesture for him to go slower. 

//Older. Wearing a suit. Walked around the... building?// You shake your head. "Sorry, what was that last one?" 

"He says the strange man tested your windows to see if they were locked. Sorry, hon, we gotta go. Text if something goes bad, okay?" She hugs you briskly before the two head out.<<endif>>

> [["Hey," says Emily.|day06_02]]

passages.name: day01_end
passages.text:
You're a year older now. And a year wiser. Haha.

Ha.
<<if $drunk is true>>
The empty glass falls from your hand as you collapse onto your cheap futon. It rolls across the ground, clinking against an empty bottle of... who even remembers.
<<endif>>\s
<<if $empathy gte 1>>
Before you fall asleep, your phone buzzes. A text message, from Emily. 

//I hope it wasn't weird today. Happy birthday.//
<<endif>>\s

You ask the cab driver to take you to the library instead of straight home. Maybe... maybe you'll make it in time. 

But an older man is locking up the building. An NPR totebag full of books weighs down his shoulder. "I guess I missed closing, huh?" 

He jumps a little at your voice, but recovers with a sniff. "I guess you did." 

On impulse, "Did Adrian work today?" 

The man's eyebrow is majestic in its thickness, which makes its skeptical rise more significant. "No," he says, carefully. "But she'll be in tomorrow." 

"She was helping me with a project," you explain hastily. "I didn't know how to use a microfiche... thing." 

He shrugs, adjusting the bag over his shoulder and moving towards the only car remaining in the parking lot. You realize awkwardly that the old man isn't going to say anything more, and you head home.

passages.text:
<<set $end = "a1">>\s
<<if $p6 eq 0>>DAY 7

You wake up, lonelier than you imagined you would be. Absently and hungoverly, you brew a cup of coffee. Your phone has no messages, no missed calls. You take a seat on your futon. The letters are there: cold comfort, but present. 

> [[Investigate the letters|day07_puzzle]]<<else>>\s
"Fuck this," you say out loud to your otherwise empty apartment. "This," you say to the letters, the typewriter, and yourself, "is bullshit." 

Something tells you to throw the letters in the trash. But maybe they're just a thing for later. 

For now, you really need to call Emily. You need to explain yourself. 

You need her.

You call. The phone rings and rings. 

END.

passages.text:
<<set $drunk = true>>\s
<<set $drinkCount = $drinkCount + 1>>\s
You lived together for almost a year before Emily got sick of your shit. Or the other way around. So much happened between the two of you that it's impossible to point fingers. Still, cooking dinner for her feels familiar and comfortable; Emily settles into her old habits too. 

She drifts from room to room, never settling in one place and never hovering in the kitchen. But her conversation is idle, and pleasant. "What're we having?" she says, and the question is so accustomed that you freeze in place for a moment before answering. 

"Some salad with this vinaigrette I cooked up, extra cucumbers the way you like it, and teriyaki salmon." 

"Yum!" she exclaims.

It's only after you've eaten that you realize you've finished the bulk of the wine by yourself.

passages.name: day06_06c
passages.text:
<<set $drunk = true>>\s
<<set $drinkCount = $drinkCount + 1>>\s
<<set $emDrunk = true>>\s
<<set $paranoia = $paranoia - 1>>\s
"Hey, do you mind if I flip through some of these letters? I'm so into it." 

"Go for it," you call from the kitchen. Not that what you're cooking is very complicated. But having Emily around—and being all domestic together—is giving you a disconcerting feeling of normalness. Is this how you wanted the world to be, when she left? It's hard to remember, even. 

What you do remember is that a lightly seared salmon served over Mexican-style black beans and rice was Emily's favorite meal. You break into a cold sweat as you cook it for her, recalling all the times she asked for it, back then. 

"Day by lengthy day, I wait for your hand in mine," Emily quotes, in a red-cheeked way that says she's powered through at least another glass of wine. The letter is abandoned when she sees the table, set. "Ooh, my favorite." 

She eats fast, and talks about Lilly Clarke the whole time.

//Mr. Astor,

Your deception is discovered. My parents—the lovely, honest, and bland man and woman you chose as my parents—revealed to me that I was a ward of the state. Then your ward. Then transferred cruelly to these strangers, before my mind had developed to remember you. How you must have watched. How patient must you have been.

I attempted to take my own life, you know. Who would you have seen, when you received that news: your ward or your lover? Would you have turned your sharp, observational wit upon yourself to say, "I did this. I did this to her."?

I leave for America with the Clarkes tomorrow. The war is over, and it is said that the West has opportunities for even the most modest of families with an abundance of determination. I imagine that my eagerness to leave your proximity and influence will drive our horses faster.

Lilly Clarke//

> [["Holy crap."|day06_emily]]

True, it's pretty simple. But there's nothing you can't do with a lemon, fresh sage, and a salmon fillet. You toss together an easy rice pilaf, and dinner is on the table before Emily can polish off that bottle by herself. 

"This is delicious," Emily murmurs. "You know, I wasn't kidding around. I really did miss this about you." She's probably got her bedroom eyes on, but you're afraid to look. 

"I, uh... I guess I don't have a good response for that, Em." 

"No," she says, taking a long pull of wine. "I guess that was not entirely fair."

You pass the coffee table, now strewn with letters, and the mysterious typewriter. Maybe if you were sober, you'd be able to tamp down the sense of foreboding you feel, but you're definitely drunk, and you don't even have a grilled cheese to show for it. 

Then again, even a bleary examination of your front door reveals some scoring around the deadbolt. Someone tried to tamper with your door.

You have the presence of mind to call the non-emergency hotline, at least. A desultory assistant takes down your contact information. "Anything missing?" 

"No, I guess not." 

She sighs audibly; you can feel your jaw clench. "I can log it, but I'm afraid there's nothing we can do if there's no crime. Property damage? Harassment? I'm trying to help you out here." 

You could tell her about the typewriter. But the thought of it exhausts you—cops and evidence and explaining the letters and weird calls. 

It's probably nothing, after all. <<set $paranoia = $paranoia - 1>>

passages.text:
<<set $day = $day + 1>>\s
The envelope you select has a small horse upon it. Strange: most of the little doodles have been pristine, but this one is unsteady. Haphazard. 

//Henry,

I have been exposed to a mode of thinking. My friend Robert Moore, of whom I have written often, has brought me to what he swears are the best//

Lilly's handwriting is difficult to decipher—her normally pristine penmenship is shaky and unevenly spaced. The sentence continues, but a smear of black ink obscures the text. The letter resumes:

//What happened to me, your sunshine girl? I have two eyes (lovely, you once called them) and four pale limbs (paler now, for your absence.) Add one smiling mouth to that sum, and an intellect that you swear could rival the greatest of modern thinkers. 

But I am without one thing that I dearly miss: your company. Double my riches. It would make no difference, without you to share them. The world is less two lovers now, for without you I am but a wisp of my self. Would that I had one more day to prove my worth. 

We have defied conventions before, my Henry. I shall <<if $hint eq true>>''ignore the odds''<<else>>ignore the odds<<endif>>, and you should too.

Yours, 
Lilly Clarke.//

My apologies if my last letter was overly forward. I did not intend to hurt you, as I never intended to hurt you. I woke up recently, alone, and longed for you to be there. I opened my eyes, and when you weren't there...

Emily already has a letter in her hand. "Let's read this one! It's still unopened, even. This letter has been waiting over a century and a half to be read. It's a thick one, too." 

That gives you a moment's pause, but Emily is there, watching as you slide your finger underneath the wax seal. 

//Henry,

Enclosed you will find the provisions of the annullment. Please return them, signed, to my solicitor. 

The collected evidence of your infidelity will ensure me half of your estate, despite my inability to bear your children. 

I believe truly that a merciful God has spared me from mothering your offspring. If you think that I will bear ill will instead, rest easy: once I am confident that I shall never hear from you again, I'll not think of you at all. 

Charlotte//

Emily slumps, disappointed. "I thought it would be something juicier. Oh well."

"Nah, I'm into it. I like how Eckhert keeps digging himself deeper with the gold miner and the schoolmarm lady." Well, you do. It might have been a whole episode ago, though. 

Emily glances at you suspiciously, then laughs. "You're still a shit liar." 

"You're still—"

Her mouth is soft against yours, and tastes like cherries. You can feel the cool points of her fingertips drawing your chin up, angling you into the kiss. Into her. Emily. "Emily." 

"Sorry," she says swiftly, pulling away and tucking a strand of hair behind her ear. You'd never noticed the nervous tic before, but now, everything is so clear. "That was drunk of me. And forward. Both."

//Mr. Astor,

It must be strange to be wealthy. My parents were always careful with their limited funds, but you poured riches onto me: money, gifts, and most of all, freedom. The freedom to spend or squander the fruits of your so-called generosity. 

I had wondered why the sanitarium staff were so eager to keep me. After my first attempt to leave—out the front door, would you believe?—I wondered if I was a prisoner. After my second escape attempt, I finally thought to bribe my captors.

Of course, the great Henry Astor: no longer interested in a used woman, but unable to relinquish his hold over her. Is it so with your wife as well? Are the chains of matrimony more secure than the locks of my room? 

We shall see, I suppose. I am clever, you always said. I shall escape.

Lilly Clarke//

You examine her face as you refill her wine glass—really look at it. She's blushing a little, and it's hard to tell if it's from the wine or the compliment. Was it even a compliment, really? 

"Thanks," she says softly, lifting the glass to her mouth. She empties it before speaking again. "I'll be honest. I don't really have a great grasp on what I'm doing here, but I'm having fun. It's fun... being with you."

<<if not $emDrunk>>"It's been going. I guess I can't complain, but there's a lot to be said for living consistently, if not well."<<else>>"It's... been weird. I used to hide behind you, and never really noticed it about myself. Now I'm exposed." She twirls a strand of hair around her ear.<<endif>> Her Cheshire cat smile is inscrutable and strange. "How about you?" 

"You know that song we used to get stoned to in college? I feel like that, only older." 

She doesn't stay late, but she lingers longer than you expect. When the conversation lulls, you make a suggestion:

DAY 7

You wake up, fingers curled in a death-grip around your phone. You were drunk enough that even a call wouldn't have woken you up. Is this what adulthood is like—filled with constant, palpable remorse? 

Impulsively, you call Emily. "I'm so sorry for last night," you say when she answers. 

"Don't be. It's a weird time for me too. I'm... glad you called." Her tone is warm, and you can definitely tell that she's smiling. "Hey, read me one of those letters. One you haven't read yet." 

> [[Investigate the letters|day07_puzzle]]
<<elseif $answer eq 0>>
"I'm shivering," Emily says. "Poor Lilly. Hey... Who do you think murdered Henry Astor?"

You bite your lip. The question has been nagging at you since you found Henry's note. 

> [["Mrs. Astor."|wrong]]
> [["Lilly."|wrong]]
<<if $puzzleCount gte 5>>> [["Henry himself."|right]]<<endif>><<else>>\s
"Well, either way, it's an amazing story, huh?" she says. 

You have nothing to add. It's hard enough to manage your own life—its strange little nuances and twists—let alone the lives of strangers from the past. <<if $answer eq 2>>At least you know for sure: Henry was a jackass and a coward, and you refuse to be like him.<<endif>>

"Emily," you murmur, cradling your cell phone with both hands and breathing into tiny mic, "can we try again?" 

She doesn't answer quickly. The phone goes so quiet that you think she won't answer at all. "Emily?" 

"Sure, kid," she says. "Okay." 

END.

DAY 7

Well, cool. You're a grown adult, and you crashed out on your couch, bottle in hand. Way to have a good grasp on real life. 

When you open your eyes—and it does take a while—the letters are there, staring back at you.

> [[Investigate the letters|day07_puzzle]]
<<if $adrianCount gte 4>>> [[Go to the library|day07_myst]]<<endif>>
<<elseif $answer eq 0>>\s
Lilly's fear, her abrupt escape from the triangle she trapped herself in—it weighs upon you. You flip through Recent Calls in your phone until you find the unknown number. 

"Yes?" 

"I'd, uh, like to give you the typewriter. And Lilly Clarke's letters. All of it." 

You hear the mysterious caller's breathing over the line: even and slow. "Very well. I shall arrange for a pick-up. Incidentally," he says, after a moment, "did you read the letters?" 

For a moment, you consider lying. But Lilly's pain was just so raw and strange and unbearable. "Yes. Why?" 

"Do you know who murdered Henry Astor?"

> [["Mrs. Astor."|wrong]]
> [["Lilly."|wrong]]
<<if $puzzleCount gte 5>>> [["Henry himself."|right]]<<endif>><<else>>\s
"Thank you," he says. "I shall inform my employer." 

And that's it. The man hangs up. You return the typewriter to the box it came in, padding it gently with Lilly and Charlotte's letters. You think of Emily only briefly. 
<<if $answer eq 2>>
At least you know Henry's true nature. You can hand over his legacy, knowing that he was an asshole to the last.<<endif>>\s

END.

<<endif>>

passages.text:
So there's that. An hour later, Katey is rendering her advice at a 45 degree angle. "Thanks for being my friend, Katey," you say, slipping her into a cab.

Before the door closes, she clasps your hand for a long moment. "Hey—you're going to be all right. Come over some time. We'll get stoned and watch horror movies. Like college. You remember college?" 

"Parts of it." You think your smile is wry, but your delivery must be off—Katey releases your hand abruptly, and flops fully sideways in the back seat of the taxi. You'll have to get your own.

It only takes a couple tries with your key to make it home—better than some nights, but certainly worse than others. Yay/oops.

passages.name: day04_bad
passages.text:
<<set $p3 = 1>>//Henry,

It is not enough to say I am heartbroken. You were never my noble, worldly knight, rescuing my damsel self from a life of mediocrity and loneliness. I was never that woman, young or otherwise, and your intentions were never noble.

Have you returned to your stalwart wife and her harridan's tongue, to lay your head in her lap? To beg her forgiveness for transgressions with myself? With others?

Are there others?

I refuse to imagine, lest I lose my graceful exit from your acquaintance. 

Lilly Clarke//
<<display day04_choice>>

passages.name: day05_startb
passages.text:
"Emily. She dropped off a birthday present that she bought before the thing." Katey nods in a way that says: and then? But she's hurled enough abuse at you today—you deny her gossip on purpose. 

"The box was packed with these fantastic letters..." You tell her about Lilly's messages<<if $mystery is true>> and Mr. Astor's mysterious death<<endif>>. "But now, I'm not sure. Some weird stuff has been happening." 

<<if $puzzle gte 2>>"Well, it sounds like you're on the right track, at least. This girl, Lilly. I like her." <<set $empathy = $empathy + 1>><<else>>"I never knew you to be a puzzle fan. Sure it's your thing?" She laughs in a way that eases the sting of her comment, and besides, maybe she's right. <<set $paranoia = $paranoia + 1>><<endif>>

> [["Well, yeah..."|day05_startd]]
> [["To women."|day05_starte]]

passages.name: day05_startc
passages.text:
"No, you're the day-after-birthday girl, and it's been a while since we've caught up. How've you been?" 

Your friend gives you a significant Look. It's not like you to be dodgy, and Katey is not the type of woman to let things slide. Maybe she's softening in her old age, though; under her watchful eye, you pound another two shots of Goose and she finally allows the change of subject. <<set $drunk = true>><<set $drinkCount = $drinkCount + 1>>

"Freckles wants to move us out of the city. I know we've been together for a while, but it's a big deal for me." 

> [["It should be."|day05_startc1]]
> [["Go for it!"|day05_startc2]]

DAY 7

You wake up with a start, looking straight at those damn letters. Emily is snuggled against your shoulder, and it takes a little doing to extricate yourself without disturbing her. 

You have to know what happened. 

> [[Investigate the letters|day07_puzzle]]
<<if $adrianCount gte 4>>> [[Go to the library|day07_myst]]<<endif>>\s
<<elseif $answer eq 0>>\s
The space between your shoulders itches. You turn around to find Emily, awake, her arms crossed. "Oh, good morning," you say. 

"Hey." 

You tell her about the final letter. It's helpless in you: the intrigue, the joy of solving a good mystery. She knew it long ago, and she knows it especially well now. 

"So, uh... Who killed the guy?"

> [["Mrs. Astor."|wrong]]
> [["Lilly."|wrong]]
<<if $puzzleCount gte 5>>> [["Henry himself."|right]]<<endif>><<else>>\s
Emily says, "I guess I'll head home," but you barely hear her, busily arranging the letters in chronological order. <<if $answer eq 2>>You're almost positive Henry killed himself, but how he got there... You can't wait to fill in the whole narrative for something. Maybe a book? Something.<<endif>>

"Cool," you reply. "Talk to you later?" 

The only reply is the sound of a door, clicking shut.

END.

Her handwriting now has long, messy swirls. In the margins, she's drawn a simple portrait of a woman—a self-portrait? The letter is short and unsigned:

//I hate you. Never show your face in my presence again.//

It's hard to see Lilly Clarke's emotions laid bare. She's normally so deliberate, so calculating. Now, she's just a mess.

passages.name: day03_worst

<<set $p2 = 1>><<set $paranoia = $paranoia + 1>>//Henry,

Please excuse my tone, but yet another visit has gone by with no pause in your complaints about your wife. I have no wish to appear petulant in your eyes—you have commented enough on my childishness—but I am frankly furious that you wish to waste the precious little time we have together on her. 

Cruel, awful her. I cannot stand the thought of you together, obliging her whims, when you could be at my side. My noble knight, my brave man. But not brave enough. 

Lilly//

"Have you considered my offer?" the voice says, without greeting or pause. The abruptness takes you by surprise; you hadn't anticipated anyone answering the unknown number, let alone that same guy from before. 

"Umm... Could I ask for some context?<<if $mystery is true>> I know about Mr. Astor. I know... some of it.<<endif>>"

The other voice falls silent, unbreathing, so quiet that you have to check to make sure the call hasn't dropped. "Certain estates are in position to make a great deal of money."

"Enough money<<if $paranoia lte 2>> to kill for<<endif>>?"

"Enough. You've been warned, and will not be again. You have one more call back to accept my offer."

You hang up before the mysterious voice gets a chance. But the triumph gives you no satisfaction. <<set $paranoia = $paranoia + 1>>
